Introduction

This  document  outlines  the  Trust  policy relating  to  pregnancy  and  maternity leave, adoption leave, partners/paternity leave, shared parental leave, parental leave and parental bereavement leave.
This  document  comprises  of  both  the  policy  and  procedure  and  provides  a complete guide for expectant mothers, fathers, partners and line managers.
This policy applies to all staff of the Trust. Those on fixed term contracts are afforded the same rights as permanent staff.
Whilst there are some aspects of this policy which may be relevant to bank workers, advice on entitlement and guidance should be sought from the Bank Team.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:

Outline the Trust's arrangements relating to: maternity leave and pay; adoption leave and pay; partners/paternity leave and pay; shared parental leave and pay; parental leave; parental bereavement leave and pay;

Provide all staff with access to information and support from the Trust, in order that they can properly plan and prepare for their maternity/adoption/partners/shared parental/parental/parental bereavement leave and their return to work;

Ensure that both line managers and all members of staff fully understand their legal obligations throughout the various stages of pregnancy, maternity, adoption, partners/paternity, shared parental, parental and parental bereavement leave;

Demonstrates that the Trust recognises the valuable contribution that working parents make to the organisation and therefore seeks to offer pay and benefits that exceed the statutory provisions to reward and retain staff.
Definitions

table_items.text: Additional Adoption Leave - Adoption leave of 52 weeks comprises of 26 weeks Ordinary Adoption Leave (OAL) followed immediately by 26 weeks' Additional Adoption Leave (AAL).
Additional Maternity Leave - Maternity leave of 52 weeks comprises of 26 weeks Ordinary Maternity Leave (OML) followed immediately by 26 weeks' Additional Maternity Leave (AML).

with other NHS organisations provided there was no break in service and no bank work

A working pattern which may include reduced hours, condensed hours and/or particular shift patterns. The aim of flexible working is to enable staff to balance their work and home commitments, whilst still enabling the Trust to deliver an appropriate level of service to patients and service users
Keeping in Touch Day (no more than 10) which allows you to stay involved in developments and work without losing entitlement to SMP or SAP.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
The Chief Executive is responsible for ensuring the Trust has robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
Line managers are responsible for:
Applying the arrangements described in this policy;
Carrying out a pregnancy risk assessment with all staff in accordance with this policy;
Submitting completed documents to ensure that payroll and other administrative arrangements can be completed at the appropriate time;
Maintaining contact with staff on leave in accordance with this policy.
All Staff are responsible for:
Notifying their line manager of their pregnancy in accordance with this document;
Participating in the pregnancy risk assessment in accordance with this document;
Completing application forms as required in this document;
Complying with the requirements of this policy.
The Employee Relations Team is responsible for advising managers and staff of their responsibilities and rights under this policy.
Maternity Leave and Pay
Maternity Leave (Time off work)
A pregnant member of staff is entitled to take up to 52 weeks maternity leave. The length of service will determine what proportion of this is paid or unpaid leave.
Maternity Pay

A member of staff that remains employed by the Trust whilst on maternity leave, and the contract of employment continues throughout the periods of ordinary maternity  leave  (first   weeks)  and  additional  maternity  leave  (second  26 weeks).

The Statutory Maternity Pay (SMP) provisions and the Occupational Maternity Pay  Scheme  (OMP),  which  the  Trust  offers,  are  detailed  below.  Statutory Maternity Pay (SMP) is paid for  weeks and is reviewed annually. Full details of the rates of SMP and how and when it may be paid may be obtained from your payroll provider.
To confirm the rate of SMP please use the government website details provided in the reference section of table 1 below:

data.text: The NHS staff terms and conditions of service handbook ‘Agenda for Change' will take precedence in the case of any dispute over eligibility and/or payment.

The payment of the 8 weeks full pay and 18 weeks half pay is conditional on the member  of  staff  returning  to  work  for  the  NHS  from  maternity  leave  for  a minimum of 3 calendar months. Staff who fails to return to work for the 3 calendar months  may  be  required  to  repay  all  monies  received  (apart  from  Statutory Maternity Pay or Maternity Allowance).
Terms and Conditions during maternity leave

During both ordinary and additional maternity leave, staff continues to be eligible for  their  normal  benefits  and  are  bound  by  all  the  terms  and  conditions  of employment, that would have applied but for their absence, except with regard to remuneration.
Notifying the Trust of the Pregnancy
Once a member of staff has notified the Trust that they are pregnant, both the manager and member of staff have a number of responsibilities.
The manager should:-
Respond to your member of staff's formal notification within  days;
Inform Payroll of the member of staff's intention to take maternity leave;
Ensure that a pregnancy risk assessment is completed and reviewed at least on a monthly basis;
Receive the MATB1 certificate.
The member of staff should:-
Notify your manager of your pregnancy;

Let your manager know in writing (see Maternity Application Form) no later than the end of the 15th week before the baby is due, or as soon as is reasonably practicable. The member of staff will also need to let them know the expected week of childbirth (EWC) and when maternity leave is
expected to start. It would also be helpful to confirm when a return to work is anticipated;
The earliest that maternity leave can start is at the beginning of the 11th week before the expected week of childbirth;
Where the start date changes, the member of staff give 28 days' notice in writing to their manager of the new date or as soon as reasonably practicable;

Give the line manager a copy of the MAT B1 certificate. This can be obtained from your doctor or midwife and is a certificate which confirms the pregnancy, the due date and expected week of childbirth. This is required by the Trust for Statutory Maternity Pay to be paid, if eligible;
Complete the Pregnancy Risk Assessment with manager and follow up reviews;
Where there is a risk to the member of staff or the baby's health and safety and has not been considered in the risk assessment, the line manager should be informed immediately;
Inform their manager know when the baby is born.
Pre and Post Pregnancy Risk Assessment Pre Birth:

As part of the Trust's commitment to improving staff health and in line with the European Union Pregnant Workers Directive, all pregnant staff will undergo a Pregnancy Risk Assessment. The purpose of the Risk Assessment is to assess the effect the working environment and duties are likely to have during pregnancy. The Risk Assessment must be carried out as soon as line manager is aware of the pregnancy pregnant, using the Pregnancy Risk Assessment Form. This form must be forwarded to Occupational Health, who will decide whether the member of staff needs to attend for an OH appointment. The line manager will forward a copy of the risk assessment form to Occupational Health; who will invite the member of staff to attend an appointment in Occupational Health if the information on the form deems it to be necessary.

Certain types of work may be assessed as having a negative effect; the risks will be discussed with the member of staff and their manager. For example, some professions, such as Radiography limit the amount of time that pregnant women can work.

If, following an assessment of the member of staff's condition and their work, it is agreed that the member of staff is unable to carry out their usual work, amendments to the work or working conditions / hours, or, if this is not possible, suitable alternative work may be sought This will only be necessary where the work may cause harm to the member of staff or their baby. Any readjustments of work may typically only last until maternity leave is taken.
If, despite best efforts, no suitable work can be found, the member of staff will be medically suspended from work on full pay until the risks to the member of staff

or their baby's health have passed or suitable alternative work becomes available. This will be fully discussed with the member of staff and only considered in exceptional circumstances. If the member of staff is medically suspended in these circumstances, they will still retain their entitlement to maternity pay (if eligible) and their right to return to work after maternity leave.
These provisions do not apply where your doctor has signed the member of staff is off sick, but only where they are able to come to work but unable to carry out their job due to the pregnancy.
Post Birth

When the member of staff returns to work after maternity leave, a further risk assessment should be completed of their working conditions. If it is found that either the member of staff or their baby would be put at risk were they to continue with their normal duties, the employer should provide suitable alternative work. The member of staff will continue to receive their normal rate of pay. Where this is not possible it may be necessary to medically suspend them on full pay.

Where the member of staff is breast-feeding on return to work, the line manager should consider arrangements for paid time release as a reasonable adjustment for the purposes of expressing and storing milk which may include paid time release. Line managers should provide private breast-feeding facilities for mothers returning to work that are:
Clean, private and safe;
Suitable access to facilities with a suitable refrigerator.
The member of staff may also discuss with their manager the possibility of varying shift patterns to facilitate breast-feeding at home.
Antenatal Appointments

The member of staff who is pregnant is entitled to reasonable paid time off for antenatal care, irrespective of their length of service or the number of hours worked. This applies to appointments made by a doctor or a midwife and may also include relaxation and parent craft classes. Such time off will be on full pay and the member of staff will not be required to make up the hours lost.

The member of staff should give their manager as much notice as possible of appointments, so that appropriate arrangements can be made. It will be necessary for them to produce appointment cards from the hospital or clinic as proof of appointments.

The member of staff's partner is entitled to time off during working hours to accompany them to 2 ante-natal appointments. There is no legal right to paid time off for antenatal appointments; however the Trust allows reasonable paid time off for partners to attend antenatal classes. Evidence of these appointments should be provided on request.
Earliest start date for Maternity Leave
The earliest that maternity leave can start is at the beginning of the 11th week before the expected week of childbirth.
Staff that give birth before their leave date or expected week of childbirth are still entitled to the same number of weeks' maternity leave, but this will start automatically from the date of birth.

Staff that gives birth later than their expected week of childbirth are not entitled to an extended period of maternity leave. They may be able to extend their leave by using a different type of leave, such as taking any accrued annual leave or unpaid parental leave. In exceptional circumstances for example, where the member of staff have sick pre-term babies or multiple births, Additional Maternity Leave (unpaid) may be extended by local agreement.
Sickness within the last four weeks before childbirth

If a member of staff is absent continuously from work during the last four weeks before the expected week of childbirth because of illness related to the pregnancy, maternity leave will automatically commence at the fourth week before the expected week of childbirth. This applies even if the day of absence is before the date the member of staff has notified the Trust of the intended date to start maternity leave.
The manager should:-
Seek advice from the Occupational Health Service, if it is not clear whether an absence is pregnancy related;
Formally notify the member of staff that their maternity leave has started;
Revisit the pregnancy risk assessment if necessary.
The member of staff should:-
Visit the Occupational Health Service or their GP, if it is not clear whether the absence is pregnancy related;
Start your maternity leave from the first day of absence if the reason for illness is related to their pregnancy.
Leaving the Trust employment during pregnancy
A member of staff who leaves the Trust's employment before the beginning of the 15th week before the expected week of childbirth cannot claim Statutory Maternity

Pay. They may however be entitled to Maternity Allowance and should contact the Department for Work and Pensions. 5.25  A member of staff who leaves the Trust's employment after the 15th week before the expected week of childbirth is entitled to Statutory Maternity Pay, subject to satisfying the qualifying criteria.
Pensions

Contribution to the Pension Scheme will automatically continue to be deducted from the actual pay of a member of staff who is a member of the Scheme whilst on maternity leave, and in receipt of Occupational Maternity Pay, Statutory Maternity Pay or Maternity Allowance.

If a member of staff takes unpaid maternity leave they can decide whether to pay pension contributions for this period and on their return to work, they will be given the opportunity to purchase contributions for any period of unpaid maternity leave.

Contributions will be based on the pay they were receiving the day before unpaid leave started. If a member of staff chooses to make up contributions, the Trust will pay the employer's contributions for that period. If a member of staff chooses not to pay, the relevant period will not count for Pension purposes.
Further queries should be referred to the Trust's pension advice provider.
Annual leave
A member of staff on maternity leave whether paid or unpaid, will continue to accrue both statutory and any additional contractual holiday entitlement during their maternity leave period.

The member of staff needs to work out when they wish to take their annual leave either before or after their maternity leave, it must be booked and agreed with the member of staff's manager. Annual leave cannot be taken between ordinary maternity leave and additional maternity leave.
Keeping in touch (KIT) days

‘Keep in Touch‘ (KIT) days whereby those on maternity (or adoption) leave can (but are not obliged to) agree with their employer to return to work for up to ten days during their Statutory Maternity Leave, without bringing the maternity leave to an end or losing SMP. Any work must be by agreement and neither the employer nor the member of staff can insist upon it.

KIT days do not have to be consecutive and may be used for any work-related activity such as training, meetings, conferences or other activities which would help the member of staff keep in touch with her workplace and any changes occurring in it. Any days of work will not extend the maternity leave period. The member of staff will be paid at their basic daily rate, for the hours worked (normal pay) less appropriate maternity leave payment for KIT days worked. Working for part of any day will count for one KIT day.
Shared Parental Leave and Pay

Shared Parental Leave (SPL) and pay (ShPP) has been introduced to allow parents more flexibility in how they care for their child during the first year. The member of staff will have the right to share up to 50 weeks leave with their partner to care for their child (minus the period spent on maternity leave), see the Shared Parental Leave and Pay section 8. The changes do not affect the existing entitlement to maternity leave, paternity leave and/or parental leave.
Pre Term Births
If the member of staff's baby is born alive prematurely, they will be entitled to the same amount of maternity leave and pay, as if the baby was born at full term:

If the baby is born before the th week before the week in which it was due and the member of staff was at work during the week in which the birth occurred, maternity leave will start on the first day of absence;

If the baby is born before the th week of the due date and the member of staff is absent on certified sickness during the week of childbirth, maternity leave will start at the beginning of the actual week of childbirth;

If the baby is born before the th week of due date and the baby is still in hospital, the member of staff may split their maternity leave entitlement. Taking a minimum of 2-weeks leave immediately after the birth and the rest of their leave following the baby's discharge from hospital.
Miscarriages or Still births
If stillbirth occurs after the twenty-fourth week of pregnancy, the member of staff will be entitled to their full maternity leave and pay.
If the miscarriage occurs before the twenty-fourth week of pregnancy, normal sick leave provisions will apply as necessary.
Returning to Work on Reduced hours

A member of staff may request in line with the Trust's Flexible Working Policy to return to work from maternity leave on a part-time, job-share or other flexible working arrangements. As stated in the Flexible Working Policy, requests cannot be guaranteed to be granted. In some instances where a member of staff
changes their working hours, the annual leave entitlement on return to work will need to be recalculated.

During the period of paid ordinary maternity leave, a member of staff may not work any bank shifts. However, during the period of unpaid additional maternity leave, a member of staff may work bank shifts.
If the member of staff wishes to return to work earlier than previously advised, they must give  days' notice to their manager of the change.

A member of staff who decides not to return to work after the birth of their baby is still required to advise the Trust in writing, providing the necessary notice as specified in their terms and conditions of employment.
Role on return from work
A member of staff who returns to work after a period of Ordinary Maternity Leave is entitled to return to the job the member of staff occupied immediately before their maternity leave began.

If a member of staff returns to work after a period of Additional Maternity Leave they also retain the right to return to work in their original job. In this case, the member of staff has the right to return to another suitable job on the same terms and conditions.

Line managers must contact their HR Business Partner at the earliest opportunity in the event that it becomes likely that a member of staff may not be able to return to their old job following additional maternity leave.
Failure to Return to Work

If a member of staff who has notified their manager of their intention to return to work for the same or a different NHS employer for a minimum period of three months after their maternity leave has ended but then fails to do so within 15 months of the beginning of their maternity leave, will be liable to refund the whole of their maternity pay, less any Statutory Maternity Pay, received.
Increments

Absence on maternity leave, whether paid or unpaid, counts towards service for annual increments and for the purposes of any service qualification period for additional annual leave and contractual sick pay.
Fixed Term or Training Contracts

Staff on fixed term or training contracts which expire after the 11th week before the expected week of childbirth and who have more than 12 months continuous NHS service shall have their contracts extended so as to allow them to receive 26-weeks contractual maternity leave.
Absence on maternity leave (paid or unpaid) up to 52 weeks before a further NHS appointment shall not constitute a break in service.

If there is no right of return to be exercised because the contract would have ended if pregnancy and childbirth had not occurred, the repayment provisions relating to the failure to return to work will not apply.
Staff on fixed term contracts who do not meet the 12 months continuous service condition may still be entitled to statutory maternity pay or maternity allowance.
Rotational Training Contracts

Where a member of staff is on a planned rotation of appointments with one or more NHS employers as part of an agreed programme of training, the member of staff shall have the right to return to work in the same post or in the next planned post irrespective of whether the contract would otherwise have ended if pregnancy and childbirth had not occurred. In such circumstances the member of staff's contract will be extended to enable them to complete the agreed programme of training.
Assistance with Childcare Nursery
The Trust has nursery facilities operating within its grounds or near to each main site providing the option of childcare facilities for working parents close to work:
Basildon Hospital – an independent Seymour House nursery offering Ofsted approved childcare near to the main hospital site. Please contact the Nursery Manager, on 01268 464422;

Broomfield Hospital has the Broomfield Hospital Day Nursery operating on site in a converted coach house offering Ofsted approved childcare. It is a Seymour House nursery. Please contact the Nursery Manager on 01245 514035;
Southend Hospital has Ladybird Nursery on site offering Ofsted approved childcare. Please contact the Nursery Manager on 01702 385330.
Free Nursery Spaces

The Government provides free nursery spaces to all 3 to 4-year-olds in England whereby all parents can get 570 free hours per year. It's usually taken as 15 hours a week for 38 weeks of the year, but you can choose to take fewer hours over more weeks. You may be able to get up to 30 hours free childcare (1,140 hours per year, which you can choose how you take) if you are eligible, to find out go to: https://www.gov.uk/30-hours-free-childcare
Childcare support
Please go to https://www.gov.uk/help-with-childcare-costs/childcare-vouchers for information on the various schemes currently operating.
Adoption Leave and Pay
Entitlements
Staff may take adoption leave when a child is placed with them for adoption, provided they meet certain qualifying conditions.

Where a couple are adopting jointly, only one (who will be identified as the primary carer) may take Adoption Leave and receive Adoption Pay. The partner will be entitled (subject to meeting certain eligibility criteria) to take a maximum of two weeks leave paid partners leave, shared parental leave and/or a period of unpaid parental leave.
A parent in a same-sex relationship may qualify for adoption leave, as may the male partner in a heterosexual relationship.
Staff may take adoption leave when they are the intended parents of a surrogacy arrangement through a registered adoption agency or a parental order.
Eligibility
To qualify for adoption leave the member of staff must:
Be newly matched with a child (under the age of 18) for adoption by a registered adoption agency, and should be able to provide documentary evidence, in the form of a matching certificate
Be legal parents following an application for adoption or parental order as part of a surrogacy arrangement
Have notified the agency that they agree to the child being placed
Have notified their manager of when they want to take their leave within 7 days of the date they are notified of a match, and giving at least 28 days'
notice in writing of the date they want their leave to start
Earned more than the lower earnings limit in the  weeks prior to the notification of placement (information on the lower earnings limit can be sought from the Human Resources Team)
Have at least 26 weeks' continuous service by the end of the week they are notified of a match with the child
The member of staff does not qualify for Statutory Adoption Leave or Pay if they:
Arrange a private adoption;
Become a special guardian or kinship carer;
Adopt a stepchild;
Adopt a family member.
How much leave may be taken?

If eligible, the member of staff may take up to 26 weeks' ordinary adoption leave (OAL), followed immediately by a further 26 weeks of additional adoption leave (AAL), giving an overall entitlement of 52 weeks' leave.
Adoption leave is not meant to cover the period spent traveling overseas to arrange the adoption or for visiting the child. Other leave arrangements will need to be discussed to cover such periods.
Only one period of leave is permitted for each placement regardless of how many children are placed at that time as part of the same arrangement.
Pay and benefits during adoption leave

The member of staff is eligible for contractual adoption pay if they have at least 12 months' continuous NHS service by the end of the week in which they are notified of a match by an adoption agency and meet the eligibility criteria defined above.
Contractual Adoption Pay:
For the first 8 weeks of absence, they will receive full pay, less any SAP receivable;
For the next 18 weeks, they will receive half of full pay, plus any SAP receivable providing the total receivable does not exceed full pay;
For the next 13 weeks, they will receive SAP. Thereafter they have the option of taking a further 13-weeks unpaid adoption leave.
If the member of staff does not have 12 months continuous service as defined but are eligible for Adoption Leave, they will be eligible for Statutory Adoption Pay (SAP) if:
They have at least 26 weeks continuous service by the end of the week in which they are notified of a match with the child, and
They have earned more than the lower earnings limit in the 8 weeks prior to the notification of placement.
The member of staff will be eligible for SAP and full details of the rates of SMAP and how and when it may be paid may be obtained from their payroll provider.
If they are not eligible for SAP, they should talk to their adoption agency about the financial support available to adopters in these circumstances. They may also be eligible for income support.
Commencement of leave
The member of staff can start their leave on any day of the week, from either:
The actual date of the child's placement, or
A predetermined date no more than  days before the expected date of placement.
Where the adopted child is currently overseas, the member of staff can start their leave either:
From the date the child enters Great Britain;
A pre-determined date no later than  days after the date the child enters Great Britain.

If, for some reason, the placement is not successful and ends after the adoption leave period has begun, the member of staff will be allowed to continue their adoption leave for a maximum of 8 weeks after the end of week the placement ends or until the end of the maximum leave period, if that is sooner. They are required to notify their manager if the placement has been disrupted or has ended and confirm the new date of their return to work.

If the member of staff starts their adoption leave before the child is placed, they need to be sure that the placement is going ahead. If it is delayed once they have started their leave, they cannot stop their leave and start it again at a later date.
For Surrogacy arrangements, adoption leave can start the day of the birth or the day after.

Shared Parental Leave and Pay has been introduced which allows parents more flexibility in how they care for their child during the first year. Eligible parents will have the right to share leave to care for their child, minus the period that the
primary carer has spent on adoption leave, please see Part 4: Shared Parental Leave. The changes do not affect the existing entitlement to paternity leave and/or parental leave.
Notice period to take leave and receive pay

The member of staff must notify their manager of their intention to take adoption leave within seven days of being notified of a match by the adoption agency, unless this is not reasonably practicable.
The member of staff must provide the following details in writing:
They intend to take adoption leave;
When the child is expected to be placed;
When they would like their Leave/SAP period to commence.
Notification is provided by:
a) Using the Adoption Leave Application Form (refer to Appendix 1)
b) The member of staff must give their declaration in writing to their manager that they have chosen to receive SAP and not SPP
c) They must also complete Form SC4 entitled “Becoming an Adoptive Parent”, no later than 28 days before they want leave to start, unless this is not reasonably practicable

The member of staff must provide their manager with documentary evidence of the placement for adoption in the form of a matching certificate. Parents who adopt from overseas should provide a copy of written official notification confirming that they are eligible to adopt and have been assessed and approved as a suitable adoptive parent. If they are unable to secure such documentary evidence and/or do not use a registered adoption agency and therefore are not able to secure a matching certificate, they will not be eligible.
If adopting from overseas, the member of staff must notify their line manager of the date their child entered the U.K. This must be given within 28 days of the child's entry into the U.K.

The member of staff can change their mind over when they would like to commence their adoption leave provided they give at least 28 days' notice, in writing, of the change (unless this is not reasonably practicable).

For surrogacy arrangements, the member of staff must notify their manager at least 15 weeks before the baby is due that they intend to take adoption leave and provide documentary evidence that they are eligible to adopt or have a parental order.
Time off work for appointments
The member of staff will be able to take paid time off for up to  adoption appointments. Their partner will be entitled to take unpaid time off for up to 2 appointments.
This will also apply if the member of staff has a surrogacy arrangement and will be applying for a Parental Order for the child.
Working during adoption leave

The member of staff can work during their adoption leave on a 'keeping-in-touch' (KIT) day without bringing their adoption leave to an end or losing their adoption pay. They can work for up to 10 KIT days during their adoption leave. The days can be worked either as individual days or in blocks.

The member of staff must agree with their manager that they will work on a KIT day. The member of staff does not have to work on an offered day if they do not wish to do so. They are not obliged to work any KIT days that are offered.
The member of staff will be paid at their basic daily rate for the hours worked less appropriate adoption leave payment. Working part of any day will count as 1 KIT day.
The total duration of their adoption leave period will remain as  weeks regardless of whether or not they work on a KIT day.
Contact during adoption leave

During the adoption leave period, their manager may make reasonable contact with them. They may be contacted, e.g. to discuss whether or not their planned date of return to work has changed or is likely to do so, or to discuss any flexible working arrangements that would make their return to work easier, service developments etc. They are also entitled to make reasonable contact with their manager during their adoption leave.
Contractual terms and conditions during adoption leave
During adoption leave (both paid and unpaid) the member of staff will retain all of their contractual rights except remuneration.
Pensions
Pension rights and contributions shall be dealt with in accordance with the provisions of the NHS Superannuation Regulations.
Increments

Absence on adoption leave, whether paid or unpaid, counts towards service for annual increments and for the purposes any service qualification period for additional annual leave and contractual sick pay.
Returning to work
Before commencement of leave, the member of staff must agree with their manager the date of your return to work.
The member of staff is entitled to return early from leave. However, a written request must be submitted to their manager at least  weeks before their intended date of return.
If the adoption placement is disrupted and the member of staff is returning earlier than expected, they will still need to give the 8 weeks' notice of early return.

If the member of staff attempts to return early without notification, their date of return may be delayed by up to 8 weeks, provided this does not extend beyond the end of their maximum leave entitlement.

In most cases the member of staff will be eligible to make a request to work flexibly, and may apply for alternative working arrangements. All requests should be made using the form attached to the Flexible Working Policy and Procedure. Copies of the policy can be accessed on the Hub or by contacting the Human Resources Team. Managers and staff wishing to explore the possibility of flexible working should contact their Human Resources Adviser for advice.
Role on return from work

A member of staff who returns to work after a period of Ordinary or Additional Adoption Leave is entitled to return to the job the member of staff occupied immediately before their maternity leave began.

Line managers must contact their HR Business Partner at the earliest opportunity in the event that it becomes likely that a member of staff may not be able to return to their old job following additional adoption leave.
Not Returning To Work

If the member of staff does not intend to work with either the same or another NHS employer for a minimum period of 3 months after their adoption leave has ended, they will only be entitled to SAP for the period of their adoption leave.
If the member of staff does not intend to return, any outstanding annual leave should, ideally, be taken before the commencement of adoption leave.

If the member of staff had originally intended to return to work and later decided not  to  return  to  their  current  or another  NHS  employer  within  15-months  of commencing their adoption leave, they will have to refund the whole of their contractual adoption pay less any SAP.
Partners/Paternity Leave and Pay
Entitlements
Staff may be entitled to partners/paternity leave and pay if their partner is having a baby, adopting a child or having a baby through a surrogacy arrangement.
Eligibility for Leave  Staff is entitled to 2 weeks partners/paternity leave, which are either:
Biological / adoptive parents;
Same sex partners, civil partners or having parental responsibility under the Children's Act;
Nominated carers.
Eligibility for pay

Eligible staff with 12 months continuous service by the EWC or EDP will be entitled to occupational paternity pay (OPP) at full-pay (based on average earnings less any SPP) for either 1 week or 2 consecutive weeks. Leave must be taken in full and consecutive weeks, a week being a period of 7 days, and taken within 56 days of the child's birth or placement.

Eligible staff with 26 weeks service by the 15th week before the expected week of childbirth, or by the end of the week in which are notified of a match will be entitled to one or 2 consecutive weeks of Statutory Paternity Pay, if their average weekly earnings are higher than the lower earnings limit for National Insurance purposes.

Reasonable paid time off will also be provided for both the member of staff and their partner to attend antenatal classes. Evidence of these appointments may need to be provided to their manager where required.
Notice of intention to take leave
The member of staff must inform their manager of their intention to take partner's leave:
During the 15th week before the expected week of childbirth, or
Within 7 days of the adopter being notified by their adoption agency that they have been matched with a child, unless this is not reasonably practicable.
The member of staff must inform their manager, using the Application for Partners/Paternity Leave form:
The date on which the adopter was notified of having been matched with the child;
The expected week of childbirth / placement;
Whether the member of staff wishes to take one or 2 weeks' leave;
When the member of staff wants to start their leave.

The member of staff must also complete Form SC3 entitled ‘Becoming a Parent' or Form SC4 entitled “Becoming an Adoptive Parent”, no later than 28 days before they want to start their leave, unless this is not reasonably practicable. Both forms are available from Human Resources or can be downloaded from the HM Revenue and Customs website at the links below.
Commencement of partners leave

Partners leave can commence on any day of the week on or following the birth of the child, or in cases of adoption, the date of the child's placement, but must be completed within 56 days of the birth or placement of the child.
Only one period of leave is available to staff, irrespective of whether it is a multiple birth or more than one child is placed together.
Form SC3: www.hmrc.gov.uk/forms/sc3.pdf Form SC4: www.hmrc.gov.uk/forms/sc4.pdf
Shared Parental Leave and Pay
Entitlement

Shared Parental Leave (SPL) enables the member of staff and their partner to choose how to share the care of  their child during the first year of birth or adoption. Its purpose is to give parents more flexibility in considering how to best care for and bond with their child. Eligible mothers and fathers will have the right to share up to 50 weeks leave to care for their child (minus the period that the mother has spent on maternity leave).

Eligible mothers can bring their maternity leave and pay period to an end early and convert the outstanding period of maternity leave and statutory maternity pay into a period of SPL and ShPP that can be taken by either parent. SPL can be taken in a more flexible way than maternity leave. It does not have to be a single continuous period; leave periods can be as little as a week and both parents can be absent from work at the same time.

The changes do not affect the existing entitlement to maternity leave or paternity leave, which will continue unaffected. Parents can exercise the new right to shared parental leave where the mother curtails or ends her maternity leave early, but the mother must take at least 2 weeks compulsory maternity leave before doing so.
SPL should not be confused with parental leave, which is unaffected by SPL. Parental leave is an entitlement to up to 18 weeks unpaid leave, please see section  of this policy.
Eligibility for Leave
SPL can only be used by 2 people:
Mother/primary carer and one of the following:
They must both share the main responsibility for the care of the child at the time of the birth/placement for adoption.
Additionally the member of staff must satisfy each of the following criteria:

Be or have been entitled to maternity/adoption leave, or they must be/have been entitled to statutory maternity/adoption pay or maternity allowance and must have ended or given notice to reduce any maternity/adoption entitlements;
be working for the Trust at the start of each period of SPL;
have a minimum of 26 weeks' service at the end of the 15th week before the child's expected due date/matching date;

their partner must meet the ‘employment and earnings test' requiring them in the 66 weeks leading up to the child's expected due date/matching date to have worked for at least 26 weeks and earned an average of at least £30 (this is correct as of 2015 but may change annually) a week in any 13 of those weeks;
Give 8 weeks notification of SPL and provide evidence as required.
How much leave can I take?

The member of staff is entitled to take up to 50 weeks SPL during the child's first year in their family. The number of weeks available is calculated using their entitlement to maternity/adoption leave, which allows them to take up to 52 weeks' leave:
If the member of staff is taking maternity leave, SPL can be taken after the member of staff has completed the legally required 2 weeks of maternity leave immediately following the birth of the child
If the member of staff is taking adoption leave, SPL can be taken after taking at least 2 weeks of adoption leave

The father/partner/spouse can take SPL immediately following the birth/placement of the child, but may first choose to exhaust any paternity leave entitlements (as the father/partner cannot take paternity leave or pay once they have taken any SPL or Shared Parental Pay)

If the member of staff chose to end their end your maternity/adoption leave entitlement early then the member of staff and/or your partner may opt-in to the SPL system and take any remaining weeks as SPL. The member of staff may start SPL by returning to work before the full entitlement of 52 weeks has been taken, or give notice to curtail their leave at a specified future date. Where they give notice to end early or curtail their maternity/adoption entitlement then their partner can take leave while they are still using their maternity/adoption entitlements.
SPL will generally commence on their chosen start date and if the member of staff is eligible to receive Shared Parental Pay (ShPP) they may be paid for some, or all, of the SPL period.
SPL must end no later than one year after the birth/placement of the child. Any SPL not taken by the first birthday or first anniversary of placement for adoption is lost.

SPL can only be taken in complete weeks but may begin on any day of the week. For example if a week of SPL began on a Tuesday it would finish on a Monday. Where a member of staff returns to work between periods of SPL, the next period of SPL can start on any day of the week.
Continuous leave

SPL can be for a period of continuous leave, which means taken in a single unbroken period of leave (for example, 6 weeks in a row). You can take a continuous block of leave, as long as it does not exceed the total number of weeks of SPL available and the employer has been given at least 8 weeks' notice.
Discontinuous leave

SPL can be for 2 or more periods of discontinuous leave, which means asking for a set number of weeks of leave over a period of time, with breaks between the leave where the member of staff returns to work (for example, an arrangement where they take 6 weeks of SPL and work every other week for a period of 3 months).
Notification of shared parental leave

The member of staff must provide written notification to their manager of their entitlement to SPL and intention to take SPL at least 8 weeks before the SPL is due to start. The member of staff is expected to provide notification using the appropriate Shared Parental Leave Application Form. There are separate application forms for the mother and their partner. This will provide their manager with details of their SPL entitlement, details of their partner and the length and proposed dates of the SPL. As part of their application, the Trust will request further evidence of eligibility:
Name and business address of their partner's employer (if no longer employed or is self-employed their contact details must be given instead);
In the case of biological parents, a copy of the child's birth certificate (or, where one has not been issued, a declaration as to the time and place of the birth);

In the case of an adopted child, documentary evidence of the name and address of the adoption agency, the date on which they were was notified of having been matched with the child and the date on which the agency expects to place the child for adoption. In order to be entitled to SPL, the member of staff must produce this information within  days of request.

In response to the member of staff's SPL application, they will receive either confirmation from their manager that their request has been agreed, or their manager will arrange to meet with them to discuss their request within  days of receipt of application. This will provide an opportunity to agree an arrangement that meets both the needs of the parents and the Trust. The purpose of the meeting is to discuss in detail the leave proposed and what will happen while the member of staff is away from work.

The discussion may focus on how the leave proposal could be agreed, whether a modified arrangement would be agreeable to the member of staff and the Trust. The Trust will consider a discontinuous leave notification but has the right to refuse it. If the leave pattern is refused, the member of staff can either withdraw the request within 15 days or can take the leave in a single continuous block. If the member of staff chooses to take the leave in a single continuous block, the member of staff has until the 19th day from the date the original notification was given to choose when they want the leave period to begin. The leave cannot start sooner than 8 weeks from the date the original notification was submitted. If the member of staff does not choose a start date then the leave will begin on the first leave date requested in the original notification.

The decision will be given in writing with 14 calendar days from the date the leave request was submitted. The member of staff will be informed in writing of the decision as soon as is reasonably practicable, but no later than the 14th day after the leave notification was made. The request may be granted in full or in part: for example, the organisation may propose a modified version of the request.
If the member of staff is considering taking SPL, they can contact the Employee Relations team to arrange an informal discussion regarding your entitlement and plans.
Changes to arranged shared parental leave

The member of staff can change/vary or cancel an agreed and booked period of SPL by submitting the Notification of a Change to Shared Parental Leave Form at least 8 weeks before the date of the change. Any new start date cannot be sooner than 8 weeks from the date of the request.

The member of staff may submit up to 3 separate notifications for continuous periods of leave. Any change or cancellation notification, including notice to return to work early, will usually count as a new notification reducing their right to book/vary leave.  Any change/variation will be confirmed in writing by their manager.
Statutory Shared Parental Pay (ShPP)

Shared Parental Pay (ShPP) refers to the sharing of the statutory maternity/ adoption pay (SMP/SAP) the member of staff is entitled to during maternity/ adoption leave. This does not include contractual maternity/adoption pay. The member of staff needs to understand contractual maternity/adoption pay may be more than SMP/SAP and by curtailing or ending maternity/adoption leave early may reduce their entitlement to contractual maternity/adoption pay.

The member of staff may be entitled to take up to 37 weeks ShPP while taking SPL. The amount of weeks available will depend on the amount by which they reduce their maternity/adoption pay period or maternity allowance period.
ShPP may be payable during some or all of SPL, depending on the length and timing of the leave.
In addition to meeting the eligibility requirements for SPL, a member of staff seeking to claim ShPP must further satisfy each of the following criteria:
Be or have been entitled to statutory maternity/adoption pay or maternity allowance and must have reduced their maternity/adoption pay period or maternity allowance period;
Intend to care for the child during the week in which ShPP is payable;
Have an average weekly earnings for the period of 8 weeks leading up to and including the th week before the child's expected due date/matching
date are not less than the lower earnings limit in force for national insurance contributions;   Remain in continuous employment until the first week of ShPP has begun.
Where the member of staff is entitled to receive ShPP, a Shared Parental Leave application form must be submitted to their manager at least 8 weeks before receiving any ShPP,
ShPP payments that are due will be paid at a rate set by the Government for the relevant tax year.
Terms and conditions during shared parental leave
During the period of SPL, the member of staff's contract of employment continues and they are entitled to receive all their contractual benefits, except for remuneration.

Pension contributions will continue to be made during any period when the member of staff is receiving ShPP but not during any period of unpaid SPL. The member of staff's contributions will be based on actual pay, while the organisation's contributions will be based on the salary that they would have received had they not been taking SPL.
Annual leave and bank holidays

Annual leave and bank holidays are integrated into “leave”. The member of staff will continue to accrue leave for both the paid and unpaid parts of SPL. The member of staff will not be able to take leave whilst they are on either paid or unpaid SPL.
Leave can be taken during any period where the member of staff has returned to work between blocks of SPL. A request for leave should be made in the usual way.

Where the amount of accrued leave exceeds normal carryover provisions, it may be beneficial to both the manager and member of staff for the member of staff to take leave before and/or after the SPL period. The amount of leave to be taken in this way, or carried over, should be discussed between the member of staff and their manager.
Contact during shared parental leave

During the shared parental leave period, both the manager and member of staff may wish to maintain reasonable contact. The frequency and nature of contact will depend on various factors, including the nature of the member of staff's work, any agreement that they may have reached prior to the start of SPL, communication of important information including changes in the workplace, discussing whether or not the planned date of return to work has changed or is likely to do so, any flexible working arrangements that would make their return to work easier etc. The method and frequency of contact should be agreed with the member of staff and their manager
Working during shared parental leave – ‘split' days

The member of staff can agree to work for the Trust (or attend training) for up to 20 days. These are known as "Shared Parental Leave in Touch" or "SPLIT" days. Any work carried out on a day or part of a day shall constitute a day's work for these purposes.

The member of staff must agree with their manager that they will work on a SPLIT day. They do not have to work on such a day if they do not wish to do so and are not obliged to work any SPLIT days that are offered. Any work undertaken is a matter for agreement between the Trust and the member of staff. Their manager will consider issues that may impact on determining these dates, including childcare costs, on-site nursery, breast feeding facilities etc. The SPLIT days can be used, among other things, to address departmental issues, including a peak in workload, a project or piece of work that would benefit from their input, attend in-house development opportunities, CPD opportunities.

A member of staff taking a SPLIT day will receive full pay for any day worked. If a SPLIT day occurs during a week when the member of staff is receiving ShPP, this will be effectively ‘topped up' so that the individual receives full pay for the day in question. Any SPLIT days worked will not be considered an extension for SPL.

With agreement from the Trust, the member of staff may use SPLIT days to work part of a week during SPL. The Trust and the member of staff may use SPLIT days to affect a gradual return to work by the member of staff towards the end of a long period of SPL or to trial a possible flexible working pattern.
Returning to work after shared parental leave
The member of staff has the right to return to work on their existing terms and conditions.
A formal written notification will be sent to the member of staff of the end date of the SPL period.

The member of staff is expected to return on the next working day after the end date, unless the member of staff notifies the Trust. If the member of staff is unable to attend work due to sickness or injury, the organisation's normal arrangements for sickness absence will apply. In any other case, late return without prior authorisation will be treated as unauthorised absence.

If the member of staff wishes to return to work earlier than the expected return date, they should complete a Notification of a Change to Shared Parental Leave and must give at least 8 weeks' notice of their date of early return. This will count as one notification. If they have already used your 3 notifications to book and/or change/vary leave the organisation does not have to accept the notice to return early but may do if it is considered to be reasonably practicable to do so.

When the member of staff returns to work, their manager must complete a change form confirming they have returned from SPL and submit this to the Employee Relations Team. Failure to complete this form will cause a delay in payment of their salary.
Returning to work on reduced hours

The member of staff has a legal right to request to work flexibly. They are also entitled to request flexible working to enable breast feeding. The NHS is keen to promote part-time, flexible working and job share arrangements as a means of ensuring that women, particularly those with domestic commitments, are not excluded from gaining experience in a variety of posts by virtue of the fact that they may be unable to work full-time.

It is both NHS and Trust Policy that all posts should be offered on a job-share or part-time basis unless it can be positively proved that this would be detrimental to the service. Requests should not therefore be unreasonably refused. If their request is rejected, they are entitled to written reasons for the rejection. The
member of staff may also apply for alternative working arrangements. All requests should be made using the form attached to the Flexible Working Policy.
Parental Leave
Entitlement

Parental leave allows a member of staff to take time off work to look after a child or make arrangements for a child's welfare. Parents can use it to spend more time with children and strike a better balance between their work and family commitments.
Managers and staff must ensure that they keep in touch during periods of Parental Leave.
The Trust will support all staff to maintain work life balance
Eligibility

All staff who have nominated caring responsibility for a child under the age of 18 years and have 12-months continuous NHS service will be entitled to request up to  weeks unpaid parental leave for each child.

Parental leave entitlement is inclusive of any previous periods of employment. Therefore, if the member of staff has taken 4 weeks parental leave at another organisation/assignment, this will count towards their entitlement and have 14 weeks parental leave remaining. Their line manager can request contact details of previous employers to verify parental leave entitlements.
A maximum of 4 weeks each year can be taken for parental leave, unless the child is disabled. The year is calculated from the date the member of staff became a parent.
The member of staff may extend maternity/adoption leave by claiming parental leave.
Leave must be taken in weekly blocks, where the week is the member of staff's normal working week (irrespective of the hours worked per week).
Contractual rights

During parental leave, staff retains their contractual rights, except pay. They are entitled to return to the same job on their return to work. Pension rights and contributions shall be dealt with in accordance with NHS Superannuation Regulations. Periods of parental leave will be regarded as continuous service.
Notification

Applications  for  parental  leave  must  be  submitted  on  the  Parental  Leave Notification Form. Staff are expected to give as much notice as possible, ideally at least 21 days' notice giving the expected start and end dates for parental leave, or when taking parental leave immediately after the birth or placement for adoption of a child, at least 21 days before the beginning of the expected week of childbirth or placement for adoption, unless it is not reasonably practicable to do so.
The  member  of  staff  may  be  requested  to  provide  evidence  of  parental responsibility and that the child is below the age at which parental leave ceases.
Parental Bereavement Leave
Entitlement
Since 13 September 2018, Parental Bereavement Leave has been available for all staff following the death of their child or following a stillbirth.
Eligibility
All staff are eligible from the start of employment to take 2 weeks unpaid leave after the loss of a child under 18 years of age or a still birth from 24th week of
pregnancy. From April 2020, staff with 26 weeks service is eligible for 2 weeks leave with statutory pay.
Training Requirements
Training will be available to managers at the launch of this policy.
Monitoring and Audit

Appendix 2: Pregnancy risk assessment (new and expectant mothers)
PREGNANCY RISK ASSESSMENT (NEW AND EXPECTANT MOTHERS)
Occupational Health & Wellbeing Guidelines for Managers Undertaking a Pregnancy or New Mums Risk Assessment
Introduction
A new or expectant mother is defined as an employee who is:-
Pregnant
Who has given birth in the previous 6 months, or has delivered a stillborn child after 24 weeks of pregnancy
Breastfeeding
All employers are required to carry out a risk assessment for new and expectant mothers to protect their health and safety whilst at work.

These guidelines are designed to provide you with all the information you will need in order to carry out a pregnancy or new mothers risk assessment and it provides you with a step- by-step guide to help you through the process. This is not a complicated process and it is important that you discuss the assessment fully with the employee concerned. Further help and advice is available from the occupational health department.
Points to Consider Prior to Risk Assessment
Pregnant Women
Line Managers should undertake the risk assessment after discussion with the employee concerned and observations of her working practices and environment have taken place.

Each employee's capability to carry out work during pregnancy will vary greatly. The physical demands of her job, together with the individual's health status, physical strength, fitness and stage of pregnancy must be taken into account.
Problems such as fatigue, backache, nausea/vomiting, swollen ankles, dizziness can occur even in normal pregnancies.

Pre-existing  health  problems  such  as  epilepsy,  diabetes or  high  blood pressure  may increase the likelihood of harm occurring whilst undertaking certain tasks at work. Managers should take into consideration work factors such as standing for prolonged periods of time or prolonged spells of lifting and bending.
It is important that a sympathetic, flexible approach is adopted at all times.
Breastfeeding Mothers

Whilst mothers will not breastfeed their baby at work, employers are required to make provision for them to express and store milk if they wish. Arrangements can be made for this to be done through the Maternity unit.
Risk Assessment Process

Explain to the individual what the risk assessment is and why it is being done. Using the information  gained  from  discussions  with  the  employee  and  completion  of  the  risk assessment  form,  identify  and  evaluate  the  risks  to  health  arising  from  the  hazards. Discuss with the employee the risk factors (if any) identified and discuss any changes in the  work  situation  with  them.   Decide  whether  existing  precautions  are  adequate  or whether more action is required, e.g.
Temporarily adjust working conditions and / or hours.
Offer suitable alternative work.

Allow  them  to  continue  at  work  offering  advice on  preventative  measures  and raising  awareness  on  things  like  impairment  of  balance,  being  more  vigilant regarding potential spillages etc.

Referral  to  occupational  health  &  wellbeing  is  not  routinely  required,  it  will  only  be necessary if having identified the risks, you are unsure or unable to remove, reduce or control them. The employee can also ask to be seen by Occupational Health & Wellbeing.
A copy of the risk assessment form should be routinely forwarded to occupational health regardless of whether an occupational health assessment is required.
Occupational Hazards to Consider in relation to Pregnancy and New Mothers Occupational hazards can be described as physical, chemical or biological.

table_items.text: Employers should reduce lifting for pregnant workers where possible, particularly in late pregnancy. During the latter stages of pregnancy there is a shift in the centre of gravity and any load has to be held further away from the body creating extra pressure

Review manual handling risk assessments identifying the more hazardous activities. Offer alternative duties or alter the nature of the task. Minimise risk to new mothers by selecting suitable work activities and seek advice from occ health and manual
and imbalance Women recovering from childbirth by caesarean section may need to restrict lifting heavy weights for up to 3-6 months after birth.
handling teams if unsure. Review risk assessment and offer alternative duties to match the individual's capabilities as required.
Movement and awkward posture e.g. Working in restricted spaces, working at height.
In latter stages of pregnancy increasing size may prevent working in confined spaces and at height.
Avoid extreme physical conditions. Ensure suitable rest facilities. Climbing ladders during latter stages of pregnancy should be avoided when reach and balance may be impaired.

The risk of adverse effects is very small. Best excessive hours > 40hr per week There is no evidence to suggest an adverse effect of fatigue on the pregnancy However regular scheduled breaks is considered to be good practice. If employees stand for >3 hours/day, employers should consider reducing this or providing alternative work for that period of time, to reduce hours of standing to the minimum possible. Employers should reduce long working hours for pregnant workers, particularly in late pregnancy. Advice can be sought from Human Resources department.

Consider seating facility if appropriate, Adjustment to work station or work procedures may help postural problems. Ensure regular breaks and suitable rest facilities are available. Review the work regime and ensure it is reasonable and sensible in respect of new and expectant mothers.
Pregnant women are less able to tolerate heat and are prone to
Avoid exposure to extreme conditions for prolonged
fainting and heat stress. Breastfeeding is impaired by dehydration.
periods. Ensure adequate rest and refreshment facilities are available.
Exposure to ionising radiation can be harmful to the foetus directly or to a breast-feeding baby.
Local rules and guidelines on systems of work should give clear instruction on safety standards in this area.

The risk to health will be determined following COSHH assessment of the particular substance. Eg. Although a substance may be particularly hazardous, the risk to health will be low if proper control measures are in place.
Undertake a review of the environment in the context of pregnant workers. Refer to COSHH assessments. Paying particular attention to any substances classified as “toxic to reproduction”.
Exposure to viruses, bacteria and parasites

In particular pregnant women are advised to avoid working with Cytomegalovirus, Parvovirus, Rubella, Listeria monocytogenes, M.Tuberculosis. The foetus may be harmed by exposure to Rubella, Listeria, and Toxoplasmosis.

Laboratory workers who handle human blood, body fluids and lab cultures are at risk. The risks are significantly minimised by adhering to health and safety policy and being aware of both the COSHH assessments and working procedures.
